Hello, all.  I'm new to this group.  I was in the process of 
designing an implementation of NEAT when I found this group.  It's 
exciting to see that there are so many others with similar interests.

My original interest was in using temporal difference learning to 
train neural networks (via backpropagation) to play games.  The 
problem I've encountered is that learning tends to stop at a local 
optimum (the first good linear strategy).  I am considering 
NeuroEvolution as an approach to overcoming that problem that is  
inherent in a gradient-based technique such as backpropagation. 

I've noticed that several people have tried to apply ANNs to games 
such as Go.  My question is:  How would I calculate the fitness of 
an ANN for such cases?  

Using TD learning, the error function is based upon whether the ANN 
wins the game or not.  The ANN can play either a previously trained 
ANN, or even itself.  When evolving ANNs, fitness could be 
calculated similarly -- by holding some kind of tournament among the 
members of the population or by playing a previously trained ANN.  
However, I expect that if fitness is always calculated relative to 
the other ANNs in the population, the search process would again 
become gradient-based and prone to getting stuck in local optima.

Another way to calculate fitness might be to use a library of 
expertly evaluated moves (or games), and calculate the ANNs ability 
to judge them.  However, this approach suffers from three drawbacks:

  1)  one needs a library of expertly evaluated moves
  2)  those moves might not really be evaluated "expertly"
  3)  the ANN may overfit the sample, resulting in poor
      generalization

All ideas and suggestions will be appreciated.  I hope that in the 
future I will be able to contribute answers in return.  

Thanks.
